intro: Abutilon hasslerianum f. johnsonii, commonly known as the Johnson's velvetleaf, is a variant of the velvetleaf plant native to Central America. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring heart-shaped leaves with a soft, velvety texture. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers that are clustered in racemes, often appearing in late spring to early summer. Its botanical characteristics include a hairy stem and broad, lobed foliage, which contribute to its distinctive appearance. This variety is valued for its ornamental qualities and is sometimes cultivated in tropical and subtropical gardens.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon hasslerianum f. johnsonii is primarily native to the southern United States, particularly Texas and parts of Oklahoma. It is also found in northern Mexico, including the states of Chihuahua and Coahuila. This plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and along dry streambeds. It is commonly associated with limestone habitats and is often seen in open woodlands and grasslands. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endemic species in its native range.
